Graphical abstract A series of C60 catalysts supported on MCM-41 was prepared for the singlet oxygen-mediated oxidation of alkenes to the corresponding hydroperoxides (ene or Schenck reaction). The one-step wet impregnation method, followed by heating at 180°C, was used for dispersing effectively 6, 9 and 12wt% C60 onto the MCM-41 surface. N2 adsorption–desorption measurements, FT-IR, XRD, DRS and TGA were used to characterize the prepared photocatalysts. The photocatalytic activity of the C60/MCM-41 series was determined by using the photooxygenation of 2-methyl-2-heptene as a probe reaction. The results of the present study were compared with those obtained in our previous studies where the same photocatalysts had been prepared by using the successive wetness impregnation method. It was found that very effective C60/MCM-41 photocatalysts can be synthesized by applying the one-step wet impregnation method. All three photocatalysts exhibited similar activity in terms of substrate conversion, whereas their intrinsic activity which is expressed by the TON or TOF values, decreased with increasing C60 content. The replacement of the successive incipient wetness impregnation by the simpler wet impregnation method provokes an increase in the photocatalytic activity of the samples with C60 content equal to 9 and 12wt% but it does not affect the photocatalytic activity of the sample with C60 content equal to 6wt%, which exhibits the maximum intrinsic activity. The influence of the deposition method and the C60 loading on the photocatalytic performance of the C60/MCM-41 catalysts was rationalized on the basis of the different size of the supported C60 crystallites. Keywords Photocatalysis Singlet oxygen Photooxidation Supported C60 catalysts MCM-41 Ene or Schenck reaction 1 Introduction Oxidation is one of the most fundamental reactions in organic synthesis. In recent years, there has been a continuing widespread interest in the photooxidation using singlet oxygen (1O2), that is the diamagnetic first excited state of triplet ground state molecular oxygen (3O2). Literature provides many accounts of the use of 1O2 as a reagent in organic synthesis [1–7]. Among the various types of 1O2 reactions, the so-called ene or Schenck reaction [8] has inevitably drawn the most extensive attention [9,10]. The allylic hydroperoxides formed from this reaction are usually reduced to the corresponding allylic alcohols which, in turn, are valuable products or key intermediates in the synthesis of fine chemicals. The predominant method for the production of singlet oxygen involves the irradiation of ground state oxygen in the presence of dye molecules (i.e. phthalocyanines, Methylene Blue, Rose Bengal) or fullerenes, particularly C60 [10–16]. Scheme 1 illustrates the formation of 1O2 via triplet energy transfer from photoexcited C60 (3C60*) to ground state oxygen (3O2). UV/vis light excitation of C60 results in the formation of the lowest singlet excited state (1C60*). This undergoes rapid intersystem crossing (ISC) to a long-lived triplet excited state (3C60*) [15,17,18]. In air-equilibrated solution intermediate 3C60* is quenched by dioxygen via a triplet energy transfer to yield singlet oxygen. The singlet oxygen quantum yield for this process has been reported to be nearly 1.0 at 532nm [15,16]. Photosensitized reactions are usually carried out in homogeneous phase, in which case the difficult separation of the reaction products and the inefficient recycling of the sensitizer come in conflict with the basic principles of “green chemistry”. A quite promising alternative is the development of a heterogeneous process which comprises the use of solid, recyclable catalysts. Such catalysts can be prepared by immobilizing the photosensitizer on a large surface area of a solid carrier. This allows for controlling aggregation and facilitating the separation of the photocatalyst from the reaction mixture. The past decade we have engaged ourselves in a project aimed at the systematic study and development of new C60 catalysts for applications in heterogeneous photooxidation reactions [19–23]. As a result we recently reported the preparation of a series of robust and recyclable SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 supported C60 catalysts with C60 content varying from 1 to 4wt% by using a simple or successive incipient wetness impregnation method [21,22]. These catalysts exhibited higher conversion, turnover number and turnover frequency values in the photocatalytic oxidation of 2-methyl-2-heptene via the 1O2 ene reaction, compared to those achieved over the unsupported C60. In both SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 supported series the catalyst that exhibited the best catalytic performance was the one with 3wt% C60 content. In a subsequent work we studied a new series of C60 catalysts supported on MCM-41 with the aim of achieving a much better catalytic performance of the active C60 species due to the extremely large surface area of this support [23]. We started from 3wt% C60 and further prepared three additional MCM-41 supported catalysts with different C60 content (6, 9 and 12wt%). The photocatalyst with 6wt% C60 presented the higher activity. In general, the use of MCM-41 as a support instead of SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 led to photocatalysts with higher activity, which was principally attributed to the higher dispersing capability of MCM-41. On the other hand, a problem concerning the photocatalysts prepared using MCM-41 is related to the deposition method [23]. In order to prepare a photocatalyst with fullerene content higher than 3wt% C60 we needed more than one impregnation steps and an equal number of drying steps. For example, the preparation of a photocatalyst with 12wt% C60 involved six impregnation/drying steps [23]. Therefore, in order to increase the impact of the photocatalysts developed on MCM-41 we have to replace the successive incipient wetness impregnation method by a simple one-step deposition procedure. This is the main goal of this work. Specifically, the one-step wet impregnation method was employed for depositing C60 on MCM-41 surface at three different weight loadings (6, 9, and 12wt%). N2 adsorption–desorption measurements, FT-IR, XRD, HR-TEM, DRS and TGA, have been used to characterize the prepared photocatalysts. The photocatalytic activity was assessed in the photocatalytic oxidation of olefins via the singlet oxygen ene reaction by examining the photooxygenation of 2-methyl-2-heptene as a probe reaction. The influence of the impregnation method on both their physicochemical properties and photocatalytic activity was attempted by comparing the present results with those obtained previously using incipient wetness impregnation as deposition method [23]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of MCM-41 mesoporous silica The MCM-41 mesoporous silica was synthesized following previously reported methods [23–25]. In a typical synthesis, 4.15g cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, Merck) were dissolved in 180g water (double distilled water was used in all experiments). An amount of 14.2g of aqueous ammonia solution (25% (w/w), Merck) was then added to the CTAB solution for raising the pH to ∼11.5–12. Then 15g tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, Merck) were added slowly in this solution under moderate stirring. The molar composition of the synthesis gel was: 1 TEOS: 0.158 CTAB: 2.9 NH3: 155 H2O. The resulting suspension was further stirred for 1h and then hydrothermally aged in a closed polypropylene (PP) bottle for 5 days at 100°C. The produced solid was filtered, washed thoroughly with 2L of water and dried overnight at 90°C. The final mesoporous silica sample was received upon calcination of the dried material at 540°C for 7h under air atmosphere. The structure of the product was determined using High resolution-transmission electron microscopy [23] as well as porosimetry and low angle XRD (see experimental part). 2.2 Synthesis of the MCM-41 supported photocatalysts A series of C60(x)W supported photocatalysts was prepared by depositing C60 onto the surface of MCM-41. The wet impregnation method, realized in one step, was applied for depositing the C60 sensitizer. The x denotes the C60 content of the photocatalyst (wt%) whereas W denotes the preparation method used (wet impregnation). 1,2-Dichlorobenzene (MERCK, >98%) was used as solvent for the dilution of the solid C60. The required amount of C60 was dissolved in about 35mL of the aforementioned solvent using a 100mL round-bottom flask. Pre-weighted powder of MCM-41 was then added and the flask containing the resulting suspension was placed in a rotary evaporator and stirred for about 30min before evaporation starts. The evaporation of 1,2-dichlorobenzene was carried out under reduced pressure (30mbar) at 90 °C. The resulting material was then transferred in a porcelain crucible and dried at 180 °C for 4h in air. By following this protocol, three catalysts were prepared having a C60 content of 6, 9 and 12wt%, respectively. The final mass of each catalyst was 1.5g. Table 1 compiles the amount of C60 and MCM-41 used to prepare the corresponding photocatalysts. 2.3 Characterization of the MCM-41 supported photocatalysts. N 2 adsorption-desorption measurements: The BET-SSA and the pore size distribution for the MCM-41 and the photocatalysts studied were determined by conducting N2 adsorption–desorption measurements. A surface area and porosity analyzer (Tristar 3000 – Micromeritics) has been used. Pure N2 and He were used as adsorbate and inert gas, respectively. Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS): The diffuse reflectance spectra of the samples were recorded at room temperature in the range 200–800nm. A UV-Vis spectrophotometer (Varian Cary 3) equipped with an integration sphere has been used. MCM-41 mesoporous silica was used as reference. The powdered samples were mounted in a quartz cell. This provided a sample thickness greater than 3mm to guarantee the “infinite” sample thickness. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD): The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the powdered samples were recorded in the 2θ range of 2–10° for determining the pore ordering in the mesostructure and in the 2θ range of 10–80° for determining the crystal structure. For both purposes a BRUKER D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with a Cu K α radiation (40kV, 40mA, λ =1.5418Å) has been used. Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy: Infrared spectra were recorded in the range 450–4000cm−1 with a nominal resolution of 2cm−1 and averaging 5 spectra. All samples were prepared as KBr pellets and analyzed on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 spectrophotometer. Thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA): Thermo gravimetric analysis of the samples was carried out under nitrogen atmosphere (flow rate: 200mL/min) in a PerkinElmer Diamond Thermogravimetric/Differential Thermal Analysis (TG/DTA) system. A quantity of the sample (about 3mg) was placed in a platinum pan at room temperature. Initially the temperature was raised at 100°C and kept constant at this value until moisture removal and weight stabilization. After recording this weight as the initial one, the temperature was increased from 100°C to 900°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. 2.4 Photocatalysis To study the photocatalytic activity of the catalysts prepared the ene reaction of 1O2 with 2-methyl-2-heptene was chosen as a probe reaction (Scheme 2 ). The products of this reaction are the corresponding allylic hydroperoxides 1a and 1b. The reaction was performed in 4mL glass vial sealed with a Teflon-coated silicone septum. The reaction solution (CH3CN, 1mL) contained 0.03M of 2-methyl-2-heptene, 3.6mg of MCM-41 supported C60 catalyst and 5μL n-nonane as internal standard. The reaction mixture was irradiated under a constant stream of molecular oxygen at 0–5°C. A Cermax 300W Xenon lamp was used as the light source. The insoluble catalyst was kept in suspension by vigorous magnetic stirring. During irradiation aliquots of the reaction mixture were pooled out, the solid materials were filtered-off, Ph3P was added (to reduce the allylic hydroperoxides to the corresponding alcohols) and the resulting sample was left at room temperature for 20min. GC and/or GC–MS analysis was used to monitor the reaction over time. The % conversion values reported are the average of three measurements obtained from three separate experiments performed for each catalyst. The molar ratio 1a and 1b was determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. The turnover number (TON) was calculated by dividing the amount of products 1a and 1b (mol of products) with the amount of the supported C60 (mol of C60). The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated by dividing TON with the irradiation time (s). 2-Methyl-2-heptene (1) was prepared according to the procedure described in literature [21]. GC–MS analysis was performed on a Shimadzu GC MS-QP5050A apparatus equipped with a Supelco capillary column (MDN-5, 30m×0.25mm×0.25μm film thickness) and CI mass detector (5971A MS). Gas chromatographic analyses were carried out using a Shimadzu GC-17A instrument equipped with a 60-m HP-5 capillary column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical characteristics of the photocatalysts studied The supported fullerene: Fig. 1 illustrates the FT-IR spectra recorded for the MCM-41, the catalysts prepared and the solid C60. The peaks at 526 and 575cm−1 should be attributed to the presence of C60 since these are also detected in its FT-IR spectrum (see inset). The intensity of the peaks increases with the C60 content in the sample whereas no shift is observed in the absorption bands. These observations indicate that the nature of the C60 species has not been changed upon the deposition of C60 on the MCM-41 surface or upon the development of the support-supported phase interactions during heating. This conclusion was further corroborated by the linearity observed in Fig. 2 between the intension of the aforementioned peaks and the C60 content in the photocatalysts. By comparing these results with those recorded when the same samples had been prepared by incipient wetness impregnation [23], we conclude that the change of the deposition method does not affect the nature of the supported phase. The size of the supported C60 clusters/aggregates. Fig. 3 illustrates the pore size distribution of the support and the photocatalysts prepared. Table 2 compiles the values of the specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of the support, solid C60 and the photocatalysts prepared. It seems that MCM-41 consists of uniform pores with an average diameter of about 3.0nm. The deposition of the C60 on the MCM-41 surface does not actually change the pore diameter and the specific surface area of the support (see 3rd column of Table 2), while a rather slight decrease is observed in the pore volume. Therefore, the small decrease observed in the SSA of the studied photocatalysts (see 2nd column of Table 2) could be simply attributed to the quite small surface of the deposited C60. The above results presumably indicate that rather small size of C60 crystallites/aggregates are formed on the support surface which cannot affect the pores size of the support. Moreover, the XRD patterns recorded for the samples at low angles indicate the hexagonal pore structure of the MCM-41 (Fig. 4 ). These patterns are quite similar though not identical. Only a small shift of the peaks to lower angles is observed as the C60 content increases. This shows that the deposition of C60 on the MCM-41 surface has a too small effect on the porous structure of the support. The XRD patterns recorded in the 2θ range of 10–80° for the support, the prepared catalysts and C60 are given in Fig. 5 . The diffraction peaks obtained for the unsupported C60 (inset of Fig. 5) hardly appear in the XRD pattern recorded for the photocatalyst with low C60 content (6wt%). This indicates the formation of very small size supported C60 crystallites on the MCM-41 surface. In contrast, the most intense peaks of C60 (at 2θ 10.5, 17 and 20) are clearly observed in the XRD patterns of the photocatalysts containing 9 and 12wt% C60. This means that when the content of C60 on the support surface exceeds 6wt%, C60 quite bigger crystallites form on the support surface. The above are corroborated by the calculation of the mean diameter of C60 crystallites using Scherrer equation and given in Table 3 . It seems that the size of these crystallites is sufficiently large to provoke a marked blocking of the pores of the support which would be manifested by a considerable decrease in its pore diameter, pore volume and specific surface. However, this is not the case, as it can be observed from the results of Table 2. Taking into account the diameter of the cylindrical pores (3nm) one may assume cylindrical rather than spherical morphology for the fullerene nanocrystals situated inside the pores of the support. This is corroborated by the relative intensities of the most intense peaks of C60 (at 2θ 10.5, 17 and 20) observed in the catalysts (see Fig. 5), which do not follow those observed in C60 (inset of Fig. 5). The quite different analogy of the intensity of C60 peaks found in the catalysts is an indication of a preferential growth of C60 crystallites in one direction, namely a cylindrical growth inside the support pores. Comparison of these results with those recorded for the same samples which had been prepared by incipient wetness impregnation [23], leads to the conclusion that the replacement of the deposition method does not have a considerable effect on the size of the supported C60 crystallites for the sample C60(6)W. In contrast, it seems that the application of the wet impregnation method improved the dispersion of the supported C60 in the samples C60(9)W and C60(12)W. In fact, by following the incipient wetness impregnation method a considerable decrease in the specific surface area of the support had been observed for the aforementioned samples [23]. In the next subsection the influence of the deposition method on the dispersion of the supported C60 crystallites is also being investigated. 3.1.1 The dispersion of C60 supported on MCM-41 surface Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy (DRS) was used to study the dispersion of the supported C60. Fig. 6 illustrates the DR spectra of the photocatalysts prepared by wet impregnation in the present study and those that had been prepared in our previous work by incipient wetness impregnation [23]. Detailed analysis based on a spectrum recorded for the C60 solution in 1,2-dichlorobenzene and neat C60 [23] showed that the peaks appear at wavelengths lower than 400nm are due to the C60 molecules/clusters or very small crystallites. On the other hand, the weak band in the visible region may be attributed to larger C60 crystallites. Inspection of Fig. 6 clearly shows that the deposition method determines markedly the dispersion of the supported C60 which is reflected in the intensity of the wide band that appears in the visible region (400–700nm). From the above DR spectra, it can be inferred that, with the exception of sample C60(6)D incipient wetness impregnation leads to supported phase comprising rather large supported crystallites. In contrast, wet impregnation results to a supported phase that comprises smaller supported crystallites, though even in this case the size of the crystallites increases with the C60 loading in rather good agreement with the XRD results (Fig. 5). The increase in the C60 dispersion, revealed by DRS mainly for the samples C60(9)W and C60(12)W, which bring about the replacement of the multistep incipient wetness impregnation method by the one step wet impregnation method is in line with the textural data discussed before. 3.1.2 Stability of the supported C60 TGA experiments were conducted to investigate the thermal stability of the photocatalysts, especially for determining the critical temperature above which the solid C60 is sublimated/combusted on air (Fig. 7 ). Inspection of Fig. 7 shows that although MCM-41 starts losing weight from the beginning of thermal treatment, only 8% of weight loss was recorded at 900°C. This shows the quite high thermal stability of the support. Concerning the neat C60 the sublimation/combustion starts at about 500°C and only 18% of its total mass has remained intact at 800°C. The dispersion of C60 renders the support slightly more resistant to weight loss in the temperature range 100–500°C. The C60 sublimation/combustion in the photocatalysts starts at about 550°C and is completed at 800°C. It seems that the dispersion of C60 on the surface of MCM-41 does not significantly alter its stability in sublimation/combustion. Similarly, though not identical, results had been obtained for the corresponding samples that had been prepared by incipient wetness impregnation which indicates that the deposition method does not influence considerably the thermal stability of the photocatalysts in air. 3.2 Photocatalytic activity The influence of the deposition method on the photocatalytic activity. The photocatalytic activity of the samples prepared in the present work by wet impregnation has been assessed by studying the photooxidation of 2-methyl-2-heptene (1) as a model reaction. All the heterogeneous catalytic reactions were carried out under the same conditions (see experimental part). The kinetic curves obtained are shown in Fig. 8 . In these curves the % conversion of 1 is plotted as a function of the reaction time. The % conversion for the samples with C60 content 6, 9 and 12wt%, which had been prepared in our previous work [23] following incipient wetness impregnation, are also presented for comparison. In all cases the allylic hydroperoxides 1a and 1b were obtained in a 1:1 molar ratio. Inspection of Fig. 8 shows that the deposition method followed does not affect the photocatalytic behavior of the sample that had previously shown the maximum catalytic activity (C60(6)D) [23]. Moreover, the application of the much simpler wet impregnation method increases considerably the catalytic activity of the samples C60(9)W and C60(12)W. The influence of the deposition method on the photocatalytic activity is in good agreement with its influence on the physicochemical characteristics of the photocatalysts described in the previous subsections. From the practical point of view the present work demonstrates that one may apply the simple wet impregnation method for developing very active C60/MCM-41 catalysts for the photocatalytic oxidation of olefins via the singlet oxygen ene reaction. To investigate further the photocatalytic behavior we determined the turnover number (TON) and the turnover frequency (TOF) at various irradiation times over the photocatalysts prepared by wet (C60(x)W) and incipient wetness (C60(x)D) [23] impregnation. The variation of these parameters with time is illustrated in Fig. 9a and b, respectively. Inspection of these figures shows that the applied deposition methodology affects considerably the intrinsic activity of the photocatalysts with C60 content equal to 9 and 12wt%. For these samples, we observe that the photocatalyst prepared by wet impregnation exhibits greater activity than the corresponding one prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. This is not the case for the sample with C60 content equal to 6% which exhibits the maximum intrinsic activity. In fact, this sample exhibits practically the same intrinsic activity, irrespectively of the methodology followed for depositing C60 on the support surface. As already mentioned for the percentage conversion, the influence of the deposition method on the intrinsic photocatalytic activity could be related with its influence on the physicochemical characteristics of the photocatalysts described in the previous subsections. In fact, for samples with C60 content equal to 9 and 12wt% the use of the simple wet impregnation results to a supported phase that comprises smaller supported crystallites than the corresponding sample prepared by incipient wetness impregnation (Fig. 6). The preparative effect is not very pronounce for the sample with C60 content equal to 6wt% in line with the almost equal intrinsic activity exhibited by the sample C60(6)W and C60(6)D. In the context of a given deposition methodology the intrinsic activity decreases with increasing C60 content (Fig. 9). For the samples prepared by incipient wetness impregnation this was attributed to the corresponding increase in the size of the supported C60 crystallites with increasing C60 content [23]. Similar to that case, our present DRS and XRD results (Figs. 6 and 5) indicate that the same explanation should be considered for the samples prepared by wet impregnation. Influence of the deposition method on the kinetics of the model reaction. The photocatalytic behavior of the C60(x)W catalysts developed in the present work was further explored by studying the formal kinetics of the model reaction. Assuming a first order dependence of the reaction rate on the concentration of 2-methyl-2-heptene and taking into account that during the photocatalytic reaction the oxygen concentration in the reaction mixture remained constant, the following well-known equation is derived. (1) k ⋅ t = − ln ( 1 − x ) This equation relates the reaction time (t), the reaction rate constant (k) and the conversion of 2-methyl-2-heptene (x). Fig. 10 illustrates the variation of the “–ln(1− x)” appeared in Eq. (1) with “t”. A good linearity is observed in all cases confirming that there is indeed a first order dependence of the reaction rate on the concentration of 2-methyl-2-heptene irrespectively of the deposition method adopted. This shows that the deposition of the sensitizer on the support and the deposition method followed does not affect the reaction kinetics. Table 4 compiles the values of the rate constant per gram of the catalyst and per mmol of the supported C60. These values were calculated by the slope of the linear curves. As expected, the first constant values follow the same trend as the % conversion (Fig. 8) whereas the latter values follow the same trend as TOF (Fig. 9). 4 Conclusions Very effective C60/MCM-41 photocatalysts can be synthesized by applying the one-step wet impregnation method for depositing fullerene (C60) on the MCM-41 surface. The photocatalysts studied with C60 content equal to 6, 9 and 12wt% exhibit the same % conversion but their intrinsic activity, expressed as TON or TOF, decrease as the C60 content increases. The replacement of the successive incipient wetness impregnation by the wet impregnation method causes an increase in the photocatalytic activity of the samples with C60 content equal to 9 and 12wt%, but does not affect the photocatalytic activity of the sample with C60 content equal to 6wt%, which exhibits the maximum intrinsic activity. The aforementioned effects of the deposition method and the C60 loading on the photocatalytic performance were attributed to the influence of these parameters on the size of the supported C60 crystallites. In fact, the physicochemical characterization of the samples indicated that the replacement of the successive incipient wetness impregnation by the wet impregnation method decreases the size of the supported C60 crystallites in the samples with C60 equal to 9 and 12wt%. coredata.dc:description: A series of C60 catalysts supported on MCM-41 was prepared for the singlet oxygen-mediated oxidation of alkenes to the corresponding hydroperoxides (ene or Schenck reaction). The one-step wet impregnation method, followed by heating at 180°C, was used for dispersing effectively 6, 9 and 12wt% C60 onto the MCM-41 surface. N2 adsorption–desorption measurements, FT-IR, XRD, DRS and TGA were used to characterize the prepared photocatalysts. The photocatalytic activity of the C60/MCM-41 series was determined by using the photooxygenation of 2-methyl-2-heptene as a probe reaction. The results of the present study were compared with those obtained in our previous studies where the same photocatalysts had been prepared by using the successive wetness impregnation method. It was found that very effective C60/MCM-41 photocatalysts can be synthesized by applying the one-step wet impregnation method. All three photocatalysts exhibited similar activity in terms of substrate conversion, whereas their intrinsic activity which is expressed by the TON or TOF values, decreased with increasing C60 content. The replacement of the successive incipient wetness impregnation by the simpler wet impregnation method provokes an increase in the photocatalytic activity of the samples with C60 content equal to 9 and 12wt% but it does not affect the photocatalytic activity of the sample with C60 content equal to 6wt%, which exhibits the maximum intrinsic activity. The influence of the deposition method and the C60 loading on the photocatalytic performance of the C60/MCM-41 catalysts was rationalized on the basis of the different size of the supported C60 crystallites.
coredata.dc:title: Deposition of fullerene C60 on the surface of MCM-41 via the one-step wet impregnation method: Active catalysts for the singlet oxygen mediated photooxidation of alkenes
